summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing a FOIA complaint filed by The New York Times seeking records related to Jeffrey Epstein from the Bureau of Prisons (BOP). It also references coordination on handling Touhy requests from civil plaintiffs/victims in Epstein-related lawsuits, with a draft Touhy response template included.

events.description: The New York Times files a FOIA complaint challenging the Bureau of Prisons' response (or lack thereof) to its FOIA requests for Jeffrey Epstein-related records.

events.title: Coordination on Touhy Requests
events.description: Internal SDNY email discusses establishing a point person and procedures for handling Touhy requests from civil plaintiffs/victims in Epstein-related litigation.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA complaint against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) for failing to respond to FOIA requests for Jeffrey Epstein-related records, with an answer date of March 4, 2020.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) was coordinating internally to handle Touhy requests (for testimony or documents) from civil plaintiffs/victims in Epstein-related lawsuits.
Attorney Robbie Kaplan of Kaplan & Hecker was identified as counsel for plaintiffs making such Touhy requests.

The email includes extensive draft language outlining the legal framework (Touhy regulations, 28 C.F.R. §§ 16.21-16.29) governing disclosure of information from DOJ employees or records in unrelated litigation, citing privileges like law enforcement privilege.
